> Why is this failing? Seems the actuator health endpoint is not found?

very curious, because locally it works (I've just re-tested it).  But I just had a "fun" idea how we'll (hopefully) be able to see the real reason for such failures much more easily (by adding `|| docker logs`) - let's see if that helps to clarify why this fails on Travis - build is currently running...

@awasum huh, now it passed... review? :smile: May be that 30s isn't (always) enough.. if this happens more often, then we should increase that. (But the new `|| docker logs` still seems like a neat idea, to help understand future problems, so I'm leaving that in.)

This failed due to that `The job exceeded the maximum log length, and has been terminated.` problem, see [FINERACT-800](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/FINERACT-800), which I fixed in #657. @DylanRobson could you please rebase this?

@xurror Nice changes, thanks. 

All points described bellow are OPTIONAL! 

 I would propose following:
1) According to the spring doc [spring doc](https://docs.spring.io/spring-boot/docs/current/gradle-plugin/reference/html/)
`When you apply the io.spring.dependency-management plugin, Spring Boots plugin will automatically import the spring-boot-dependencies bom from the version of Spring Boot that you are using....`. So you don't need to specify version on  spring boot `dependencySet`

2) As I know when you apply bom it controls all third-party dependencies that declared it the bom. Here is a [spring boot bom](https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-boot/blob/master/spring-boot-project/spring-boot-dependencies/pom.xml). You can find spring and all related third-party dependencies there. Therefore we could exclude spring framework version and alot of third-party. 

You could generate spring boot application on Spring IO initializer and use it as an example.
@vorburger can you review this?

This change was needed because the old compile configuration now does not offer the guarantees that the api and implementation configurations provide.

Api configuration is used  to declare dependencies which will be transitively exposed to consumers of the library, and as such will appear on the compile classpath of consumers.

Implementation configuration should be used to declare dependencies which are internal to the component which will not be exposed to consumers, and therefore not leak into the consumers' compile classpath. This will also lead to faster compilation thanks to reduced classpath size.

For more info see https://docs.gradle.org/current/userguide/java_library_plugin.html

There is [already a code](https://github.com/openMF/community-app/blob/c48f89dc3397aaa16cad1cabfd6324e802e12fcd/app/global-translations/locale-en.json#L2372) that can work for this on the frontend so the fix would entail changing the `userMessageGlobalisationCode` being returned to match that.

* Create a new PR to fix what's already been merged?

Please advise

@mohitsinha The issue as I understand it is: 

- The frontend uses the `userMessageGlobalisationCode` to create the message to be displayed. 
- I created a new `userMessageGlobalisationCode` in this PR and the frontend doesn't recognise it so it displays the `userMessageGlobalisationCode` text directly.

While looking through the frontend repository that @santoshconflux shared, I realised that the message he asked me to create already existed on the frontend...which meant it already existed on the backend as well. Indeed [this function](https://github.com/apache/fineract/blob/fb1e3d7c18fdcf208654f974dcb16f3eb34dad33/fineract-provider/src/main/java/org/apache/fineract/useradministration/service/AppUserWritePlatformServiceJpaRepositoryImpl.java#L343) was supposed to handle the exception and set the correct error response.

Let's revert the changes

@percyashu FYI you don't have to keep opening new PRs, just (force) push to your same branch, and your PR will update automatically... that's much easier, and less confusing, than closing un-merged PRs, and opening #666 #668.

Build Failures are due to compilation failures re. `com.jayway.restassured`.

Try undoing the `com.jayway.restassured:rest-assured:2.3.3` dependency to `io.rest-assured:rest-assured:+` change from this PR. I suspect that will help. You could then investigate that one more separately.

In general, like @awasum said, try first building locally. I also encourage you to propose smaller more incremental changes - just go step by step, one dependency at a time, and gradually raise separate PRs. It's often easier.

@vorburger @xurror I was wondering some different deployment options for this task.

- Just restrict this to deploying the fineract backend and not worrying about the mysql instance. 
   The instance details can be passed via a ConfigMap, secret or environment variables.

- Keep the mysql container as a sidecar container alongside fineract container in the same pod.
 
I prefer the first one as it gives the user fine control over where the Mysql is hosted ( cloud, container etc).

@mohitsinha I quite liked that this includes a mySQL container, mostly because it could make it "ready to run", so that this isn't only a piece that somebody has to use as a starting point to put something together, but a fully functional, albeit certainly still demo and not prod, fully executable (think `kubectl apply` and it's up and running!) kind of thing. Let @xurror keep it? Just needs clean up.

@vorburger Can we have the mysql as a sidecar container rather than having a separate deployment for it?

I meant something along this line.
```
apiVersion: apps/v1
kind: Deployment
metadata:
  creationTimestamp: null
  labels:
    run: fineract
  name: fineract
spec:
  replicas: 1
  selector:
    matchLabels:
      run: fineract
  strategy: {}
  template:
    metadata:
      creationTimestamp: null
      labels:
        run: fineract
    spec:
      containers:
      - image: apache/fineract
        name: fineract
        resources: {}
      - image: mysql
        name: mysql
        resources: {}

status: {}

> @vorburger Can we have the mysql as a sidecar container rather than having a separate deployment for it?

@mohitsinha you technically could, as in I guess it would most likely also work, but I probably would not do that, in this case.. like, why would you? Sidecars are typically used for things which have to run in the same "Linux namespace", so that they share files and IP address and hostname, which can be useful for things like "envelopes" like "proxies" which only accept connections from localhost, or some log file scraper, or whatever. A completely separately running database wouldn't be a typical use case for a sidecar, I think, so the way @xurror is proposing it seems fine (and more "standard"), to me.
Yes. I agree with your opinion. @xurror Let's try to use standard Docker images for this one.

> @fynmanoj : Can you update UserAdministrationTest with this test case?

One of my biggest challenge with this setting up the 2 databases needed and set them as data source for the backend.
It's like one always overwrites the previously declared datasource.
So I need a little clarification, does the server automatically create the mifostenants-default database if it is not present?

No. it does not create the database by default.
We need `mifosplatform-tenants` and `mifostenants-{tenantName}`.
We also need the bare minimum records for the tenant inside `mifosplatform-tenants` to get the server running.
I'll try to make it work with the 2 databases
